msgSnippet: Overridden not overloaded, yes--it was a late night.  The other error in my message is that you instantiate objects not classes--glad no one dinged me on that.
messageBody:
Overridden not overloaded, yes--it was a late night. The other error in my
message is that you instantiate objects not classes--glad no one dinged me
on that. :-)

Just as a data point, I ran the OPs code in Eclipse 3.1.1 under jre1.5.0_05
and experienced the same test failure he had. So I'm not sure it's simply a
Java 1.4 vs. Java 1.5 thing. Of course, Eclipse uses its own compiler . . .

Jeff

"Jon Skeet" wrote:

> The problems with calling overridden methods in a constructor are
> particularly nasty when it comes to inner classes - and *very* nasty
> for anonymous inner classes which use variables in the declaring method.
>
> There was a change to the Java compiler (and the byte code spec, if I
> remember correctly) to allow certain fields to be initialised *before*
> the call to the superconstructor - fields such as those effectively
> taken from the declaring method for anonymous inner classes, and the
> hidden field containing the reference to the "parent" instance for all
> inner classes.
>
> Now, I can't find where the change is documented unfortunately - I
> thought it was a feature in 1.4, but I can't see it in the release
> notes. Anyway, I suspect that we'll find the OP was using an older
> version of javac than I am, hence the difference.
>
> In the light of this, I would after all agree with the idea that using
> an overridden method in a constructor puts you in no man's land, at
> least in the case where you're using an inner class.
>
> Jon
